prompt: Facts: Incident occurred on 25.03.2008 around 9:30 PM near Pochamma Temple, Village Gudur, District Warangal, Telangana.; Accused persons: Dara Lakshmi Narayana (Appellant/A-1), Dara Sammaiah (A-2, Appellant's father), Dara Komalatha (A-3, Appellant's mother), Manda Raju (A-4), Manda Sampath (A-5).; Allegation: A-1 to A-5 formed an unlawful assembly with the common object of killing Pasunoori Raja @ Rajesh (PW-1).; Specific Acts Alleged: A-1 stabbed PW-1 in the abdomen with a knife (M.O.1); A-2 attacked with an axe (M.O.2); A-3 threw chilli powder; A-4 and A-5 beat PW-1 with sticks (M.O.3, M.O.4).; Motive Alleged: Previous enmity stemming from PW-1 allegedly teasing A-3 (mother of A-1).; FIR: Lodged by PW-1 (the injured victim) himself.; Key Prosecution Witnesses: PW-1 (Injured Victim), PW-2, PW-3, PW-4 (Eyewitnesses).; Medical Evidence: PW-7 (Medical Officer) examined PW-1. Medical Examination Report (Ex. P-5) and Injury Certificate (Ex. P-6) noted one stab injury (3 cm x 1 cm x depth not probed) on the left side of the abdomen.; Investigative Evidence: Scene of offence panchanama (Ex. P-7), Seizure of weapons (Knife M.O.1, Axe M.O.2, Sticks M.O.3 & M.O.4), FSL Report confirming human blood on the knife (M.O.1).; Trial Court Judgment (Sessions Judge, Mahila Court, Warangal): Convicted A-1 (Appellant) under Section 307 IPC, sentenced to 7 years Rigorous Imprisonment and fine of Rs. 5,000/-. Acquitted A-2 to A-5 of all charges.; High Court Judgment (High Court for the State of Telangana): Dismissed the appeal filed by A-1, confirming the Trial Court's conviction and sentence.; Supreme Court Appeal: Filed by A-1 (Dara Lakshmi Narayana) challenging the High Court's judgment confirming his conviction under Section 307 IPC. | IPC: Section 307 (Attempt to murder - Conviction upheld), Section 148 (Rioting, armed with deadly weapon - Initial charge, implicitly negated by acquittal of co-accused), Section 149 (Unlawful assembly - Initial charge, implicitly negated by acquittal of co-accused), Section 324 (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means - Argued by defence as alternative, rejected), Section 34 (Common intention - Mentioned in context but acquittal of others limited its direct application to A1's conviction)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The act of stabbing the victim (PW-1) in the abdomen, a vital part of the body, with a knife (a dangerous weapon), clearly demonstrates the appellant's (A-1) intention or knowledge that such an act was likely to cause death, fulfilling the requirements of Section 307 IPC.", "precedents": ["State of Madhya Pradesh v. Saleem @ Chamaru (2005) 5 SCC 554 (Emphasis on intention/knowledge inferred from weapon nature and injury location)", "State of Madhya Pradesh v. Kanha @ Omprakash (2019) 3 SCC 605 (Intent inferred from choosing vital part like abdomen for attack)", "Jage Ram v. State of Haryana (2015) 11 SCC 366 (Focus on the nature of the act and intent, not merely the consequence or severity of injury)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The injury caused was simple in nature (as per medical evidence not explicitly stating it was dangerous to life), and therefore, the offence committed would fall under Section 324 IPC (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapon), not Section 307 IPC.", "precedents": ["Maturi Sanjeeva Rao v. State of A.P. (2012) 8 SCC 45 (Where injury was simple despite vital part being hit, conviction altered from 307 to 326)", "Kunhayippu v. State of Kerala (2000) 10 SCC 307 (Conviction altered from 307 to 324 when injury found simple and intent to murder not proven beyond doubt)", "State of U.P. v. Gajey Singh (2009) 11 SCC 414 (Medical evidence crucial; simple injuries generally don't sustain 307 conviction unless intent is overwhelmingly clear from other factors)"]}, {"argument": "There were material inconsistencies and contradictions in the testimonies of the prosecution witnesses (PW-1 to PW-4), making their evidence unreliable for sustaining a conviction under Section 307 IPC.", "precedents": ["Suraj Mal v. State (Delhi Administration) AIR 1979 SC 1408 (Material contradictions in witness testimonies can be fatal to the prosecution case)", "State of Rajasthan v. Bhanwar Singh (2004) 13 SCC 95 (Non-examination of independent witnesses available at the scene can raise doubts about prosecution version)", "Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra (1978) 4 SCC 371 (If eyewitness accounts are contradictory on crucial aspects, benefit of doubt may arise)"]}, {"argument": "The alleged motive (PW-1 teasing A-3) was weak and not adequately proven, diminishing the likelihood of an intention to commit murder.", "precedents": ["State of Punjab v. Bittu (2015) 14 SCC 351 (While motive is not essential for conviction with direct evidence, its absence or weakness is a factor to consider)", "Nathuni Yadav v. State of Bihar (1998) 9 SCC 238 (Weak motive can make prosecution story less probable, especially in circumstantial cases or where evidence is otherwise doubtful)", "Babu v. State of U.P. (2010) 7 SCC 189 (In cases relying on eyewitnesses with potential enmity, strong motive lends credence, weak motive raises caution)"]}]}
